content: The "Caging Prohibition Act of 2008" prohibits voter caging and other questionable challenges. The "Caging Prohibition Act of 2008" amends Chapter 29 of title 18, United States Code, by adding a section on voter caging and questionable challenges, defining voter caging documents and outlining specific criteria. The "Caging Prohibition Act of 2008" defines voter caging lists and unverified match lists, prohibiting states or local election officials from preventing individuals from registering or voting. The official must not prevent an individual from voting based on voter caging documents, unverified match lists, errors on voting records, or other designated evidence, as per the "Caging Prohibition Act of 2008". The Caging Prohibition Act of 2008 prohibits election officials from using unverified evidence like voter caging documents to prevent individuals from voting. Challenges to voter eligibility must be supported by first-hand knowledge documented in writing and under oath. The Caging Prohibition Act of 2008 prohibits formal challenges to voter eligibility based on voter caging documents, unverified match lists, or minor errors not affecting eligibility to vote. Only state or local election officials can submit challenges with valid evidence. The Caging Prohibition Act of 2008 prohibits challenges to voter eligibility without valid evidence. Violators face fines or imprisonment for up to 5 years for each offense. This does not override the National Voter Registration Act or the Voting Rights Act. The Caging Prohibition Act of 2008 prohibits voter eligibility challenges without valid evidence, with violators facing fines or imprisonment for up to 5 years for each offense.
